CHAPTER 35: THE KEEP

Date: March 17, 1432 (Evening)
Location: Niebla - Within the Captured Fortress

You make your way through the rubble-choked streets of the fortress toward the main square where the bombard has been positioned. The evening light casts long shadows across broken masonry and abandoned defensive positions. Your boots crunch on scattered debris—arrows, broken timbers, bits of mortar. The town itself is eerily quiet now that the civilian evacuation is complete.

Master Gunner Pietro Calabrese stands beside his gun, supervising final preparations. The bombard is smaller than the massive siege pieces that broke the outer walls—perhaps eight feet long, bronze barrel gleaming dully in the fading light. It sits on a reinforced wooden platform forty yards back from a barricade of gabions filled with earth and stone. The gun crew has positioned mantlets for additional protection, creating a corridor through which they can work with some cover from the keep's arrow slits.

Pietro turns as you approach, wiping powder residue from his hands. "Your Majesty. The gun is loaded and ready." He gestures toward the keep rising before you—a rectangular tower of solid stone, its gate reinforced with iron bands. "Eighty yards. At this range, with this caliber, I estimate three shots to break through the gate itself, perhaps two more to clear enough debris for your assault troops to enter." He pauses, studying the silent structure. "The keep is well-built, but not designed to withstand bombardment from this close. The gate is the weakest point—once it falls, they have nowhere to go."

The Master of Calatrava joins you at the gun position, his expression grim. "Five hundred men ready, Your Majesty. We can storm the keep the moment the gate is breached." He looks up at the tower, where Count Diego's banner still flies. "But I must tell you—a cornered madman with forty loyal knights in close quarters... even after we breach, the fighting inside will be bloody. They'll make us pay for every room, every stairwell." He meets your eyes. "We could lose fifty to a hundred men taking that keep, and every defender will almost certainly die. Baron Alfonso is praying there's some way to avoid this."
Fire the cannon master. We will see what we do next after that.

Pietro nods sharply. "At once, Your Majesty." He turns to his crew. "Final check! Elevation!"

The gunners make minute adjustments to the barrel angle, sighting carefully along the bronze tube toward the keep's iron-banded gate. One man tamps the powder charge a final time. Another verifies the stone shot is properly seated. Pietro walks the length of the gun, inspecting every detail with professional precision.

"Clear the position!" Pietro commands. The crew steps back to their protected stations behind the mantlets. Pietro takes the slow match—a length of cord smoldering at one end—and holds it ready near the touch-hole.

He glances at you one final time. You give a slight nod.

"Fire!"

The slow match touches the priming powder. There's a sharp hiss, then the bombard erupts with a thunderous roar that echoes off the stone walls. A massive plume of white smoke billows forward as the gun leaps backward against its restraints. The sound is deafening—a physical blow to the chest.

Through the clearing smoke, you watch the stone ball's flight. It strikes the keep gate dead center with a tremendous crack. Splinters of wood explode outward. One of the iron bands tears loose and clatters to the ground. A visible crater appears in the heavy timber, perhaps two feet across and a foot deep.

The gate holds, but barely. Deep cracks radiate from the impact point. The entire structure shudders.

From within the keep—still nothing. No shouts, no movement at the arrow slits. Just stone silence.

Pietro examines the damage through the dissipating smoke. "Good hit. Two more like that and the gate comes down. Three at most." He begins directing his crew to reload—a process that will take about thirty minutes.

The Master of Calatrava watches the keep intently. "They heard that. They know what's coming." His hand rests on his sword hilt. "Still no response, though. Either they're preparing a defense, or..." He doesn't finish the thought.

Baron Alfonso stands nearby, his face pale. He's staring at the damaged gate where his cousin Diego waits inside.

We wait until the gate is breached.

You nod.

March 30 - April 6, 1432

Day One: March 30 (Afternoon-Evening)

Your forces encircle Íllora methodically. Thirteen thousand troops spread around the fortress perimeter—far too many for the garrison to break through even if they tried. Siege lines are dug at three hundred yards, trenches connecting positions, supply depots established well back from the walls.

Pietro Calabrese personally supervises the artillery positioning. The western approach offers the best terrain—a slight rise four hundred yards from the town walls that provides stable ground and a clear firing line. He orders elaborate protective works built around each gun position: earth-filled gabions stacked in semicircles, wooden mantlets for the crews, trenches connecting positions for quick retreat if needed.

"Your Majesty," he explains as the works go up, "after what happened at Niebla with that sortie during the storm, I'm taking no chances. These guns are protected like the Crown Jewels."

By evening, five gun positions are ready. The bombards are rolled into place with extreme care—oxen straining, crews guiding every inch. Each massive bronze barrel is loaded: powder measured precisely, stone shot weighing two hundred pounds carefully seated, priming powder applied.

From the walls of Íllora, you can see defenders watching. Torches illuminate their battlements. They know what's coming.

Day Two: March 31 - Bombardment Begins

Dawn breaks clear and cold. Pietro walks the line of guns one final time, checking everything personally. Then he turns to you and salutes.

"Ready when you are, Your Majesty."

You nod.

"Fire!"

All five bombards roar in sequence—a rolling thunder that echoes off the hills. Smoke billows. Stone balls arc through the morning air and slam into the western wall of Íllora. The impacts are visible even from four hundred yards—stone chips flying, dust rising, the solid crack of rock on rock.

The bombardment settles into rhythm. Fire, reload, fire again. Every thirty minutes, another volley. Pietro's crews work with professional efficiency born of months of practice—measuring powder with precision, ramming shot home properly, maintaining the guns between shots.

By noon, the target wall section shows the first signs of damage. By evening, after eight volleys, the mortar between stones is visibly crumbling.

Day Three: April 1 - The Weakness Revealed

The second day of bombardment brings a discovery.

Mid-morning, Pietro is studying the wall through a spyglass when he suddenly laughs—a sharp, delighted sound. "Your Majesty! Look at this!"

You peer through the glass. Where your shots have been concentrating, you can see something the defenders probably hoped you wouldn't notice: the wall construction changes about twenty feet up. The lower portion is older, thicker stone—probably original construction. But the upper section is newer, thinner masonry. A repair or expansion from decades ago.

"They built on top of the old wall," Pietro explains, grinning. "The foundation is solid, but that upper section? That's going to come down like a house of cards once we destabilize it."

He adjusts the gun elevations slightly, targeting the junction between old and new construction. The bombardment continues with renewed purpose.

By evening, deep cracks are visible running along that seam. The wall is beginning to fail structurally.

Day Four: April 2 - The Collapse

It happens mid-morning on the fourth day.

Pietro has concentrated fire on three specific stones at the junction point—the keystone holding the upper section in place. Shot after shot hammers them. You can see the stones loosening, mortar falling away in chunks.

The third volley of the morning strikes perfectly.

There's a pause—a moment of silence—and then a sound like distant thunder. The entire upper section of wall—a stretch perhaps thirty feet wide and fifteen feet high—suddenly gives way. It doesn't crumble gradually. It collapses all at once in a spectacular cascade of masonry and dust.

When the dust clears, you're staring at a massive breach. The lower wall section still stands, but everything above it is gone. Rubble has spilled down both sides creating rough ramps. The breach is thirty feet wide and reaches nearly to the top of the remaining wall.

A cheer erupts from your siege lines. Men pound weapons against shields. Pietro is embracing his gun crews, laughing.

From Íllora's walls, you can see panic. Defenders scrambling, officers shouting orders, men rushing to the breach point with timber and sandbags to try to shore it up.

But there's no repairing that. The structural damage is done.

Day Five: April 3 - The Failed Sortie

You should have expected it.

Two hours before dawn, your sentries spot movement at Íllora's northern gate. Torches. The sounds of many men assembling.

The alarm spreads instantly. Your prepared response kicks in—captains rousing troops, defensive positions manned, cavalry mounting to respond. By the time the gate opens and Moorish troops pour out, you're ready.

Perhaps two hundred fifty men charge from the fortress—picked troops, well-armed, moving fast toward your artillery positions. Their goal is obvious: damage the guns before the breach can be widened further.

They run straight into a prepared defense.

Your infantry forms shield walls across their approach. Crossbowmen positioned in the siege works loose volley after volley into the charging mass. Cavalry sweeps in from the flanks.

The Moorish troops fight with desperate courage. They reach your forward trenches, clash with your shield wall, try to break through. But they're outnumbered five to one and attacking prepared positions. The battle is vicious but brief.

Your cavalry completes the encirclement. The sortie breaks apart—some men trying to retreat, others fighting to the death, a handful throwing down weapons to surrender.

When it's over, the ground before your positions is littered with Moorish dead and wounded. Your chaplain counts approximately fifty bodies. Another fifteen captured, wounded. The rest retreated back to the fortress.

Your casualties: five dead, nine wounded. The artillery positions were never even threatened.

The Master of Calatrava surveys the battlefield grimly. "They had to try. But we were ready. That sortie cost them a tenth of their garrison and accomplished nothing."

Days Six-Seven: April 4-6 - The Breach Widens

With the sortie crushed and no further resistance, Pietro returns to systematic bombardment. The collapsed section becomes the focus—widening the breach, clearing obstacles, making the rubble ramps more accessible for assault troops.

Day Six brings more structural failure. Another section of wall adjacent to the original breach gives way—not as spectacularly, but steadily. By evening, the breach is forty feet wide.

Day Seven: Further refinement. Pietro knocks down protruding stones that might snag assault troops. The rubble ramps on both sides are smoothed by repeated impacts. By midday, you're looking at a fully assault-ready breach—wide, accessible, with clear approaches.

And throughout these days, a new development: deserters.

"The garrison is frightened," the deserter reports. "That wall collapse... they've never seen anything like it. The commander is trying to keep order, but men are talking about surrender. The foreign mercenaries especially—they say this isn't their fight."

Don Rodrigo compiles the intelligence: "Six hundred to seven hundred troops remaining in the garrison. Commander is holding firm so far, but his grip is weakening. The breach has them terrified—they know if we assault through that gap, it's going to be a slaughter."

The Master of Calatrava joins you overlooking the breach as the sun sets.

"Seven days, Your Majesty. One major breach, garrison morale cracking, minimal casualties on our side." He counts on his fingers: "Seven dead, twelve wounded—five from the sortie, the rest from harassing arrow fire. Pietro's protective measures worked perfectly. Not a scratch on the artillery."

You study the breach in the dying light. Forty feet wide, rubble ramps on both sides, completely passable. Assault troops could advance through it in formation tomorrow if ordered.

"The breach is ready," the Master continues. "We could storm it at dawn. Or..." He pauses. "We could offer terms. Those deserters say the garrison is on edge. A generous surrender offer might finish this without more bloodshed."

Don Rodrigo joins the discussion. "Or we continue bombardment—shift to targeting the castle itself now that the town walls are breached. Break them further before offering anything."

Pietro appears, wiping powder residue from his hands. "The guns are performing beautifully, Your Majesty. Whatever you want to hit next, we can hit it."

From Íllora, torches illuminate the breach. You can see defenders working frantically to build internal barricades behind the gap—preparing for the assault they know is coming.

Day Four: April 11 - The Burials

Dawn breaks gray and somber. Throughout the captured town and in the castle above, both armies tend to their dead.

The Castilian Burials:

In the town square, your chaplains consecrate ground for a mass grave. Eighty-seven bodies are laid out in rows, washed and prepared. Many are young—boys who will never see home again. Each is wrapped in cloth, a cross placed on the chest.

Midday: The Surrender

The next four days are spent putting Íllora back together and preparing your army for the next phase.

The Wounded:

Your field hospital is overwhelmed. One hundred sixty-four wounded men, fifty-two of them seriously. Surgeons work around the clock—amputating shattered limbs, stitching sword cuts, extracting arrows, fighting the infections that always follow battle.

No violence against civilians.

The Artillery:

The Troops:

12,850 troops available (after garrison duties and casualties)

Five bombards operational

Supply lines secure from your western conquests

Morale: Steady but wary

The Master of Calatrava spreads the map before you. "Íllora is ours. Moclín is under siege by Infante Juan. That leaves the southern approaches—Alhama de Granada is the key fortress there, twenty-five miles southwest of the capital. Or we could move directly on Granada itself, though that's a much larger undertaking."

Don Rodrigo adds: "The news from those released prisoners will have an effect. Every garrison commander now knows: refuse surrender and face bombardment and assault. Accept terms and live with honor. That may change calculations at the next fortress."

Your army is ready. The bombards are loaded on their carriages. The troops are formed up. Íllora stands behind you, Castilian banners flying from its battered walls.
